text:
In town visiting for the day, and the decision (based on other Yelp reviews) to have brunch at Honey's was made.

First and foremost, this is absolutely a Hipster dive, so if you have an aversion to the casually ironic, stay away...it will only get your blood up and probably dull the taste buds just a little bit.

Anyway, looking at their menu, it is clear that there is a great amount of thought placed on taste and variety, two things that absolutely make it hard to make a choice when it's your first and probably only chance to sample the offerings. 

I settled on the Challah French Toast with Home Fries and their locally-purchased bacon. Add to that an absolutely delicious fresh-squeezed Limeaid that more than hit the spot.

First and foremost, major props for serving hot maple syrup with their pancakes and french toast, that is a special touch that you don't really get most other places. Add to that the fact that they gave a generous amount, guaranteeing that the maple flavor is absolutely present. I dug that.

The Challah French Toast was light, airy and very delicious. Three slices of this thick bread are more than enough to satisfy even the hungriest of diner. Very good choice here.

The Home Fries, made with peppers and onions were just as delicious, although I wish the portion was slightly larger. $2.50 for a modest saucer is a bit much; I would have happily paid an extra buck for a larger portion.

But by far, the absolute best part of the meal was the Lancaster County Country Bacon, which without fillers and emulsifiers, made for an excellent slice of bacony heaven. Cooked just right, with a good amount of thickness, it was a highlight of the meal.

Must admit that I wasn't a fan of the Cash Only rule, but as the ATM located in the shop had a relatively low fee ($1.50), I'm not going to let it ding the overall experience. 

One last thing: I tried a bit of the Potato Latke, and I must say...I wasn't nearly as impressed as everyone else here seems to be. It was on the dry side, and not as savory as I would have liked. If you have to choose between the Latke and the Home Fries, absolutely go for the Home Fries.

I doubt I will have a chance to visit Honey's again, but if you are in the area, I believe it's definitely worth giving it a shot.
ner_results: {'food': ['Challah French Toast', 'Home Fries', 'Lancaster County Country Bacon'], 'drink': ['Limeaid']}

text: Grabbed a bite here a while ago while waiting for my bus. It's a cute and busy spot nestled in the 30th street station with both in pub seating and tables arranged outside (in the terminal) as well. I had their Mediterranean Meze platter with some red wine and while the red wine was delicious and just what I needed, the platter wasn't the best Mediterranean food out there. I mean I didn't expect much since I was at a pub after all. Unfortunately, I felt like their vegetarian entrees were limited. Apart from the veggie burger, I didn't see anything else I'd be interested in trying which is why I picked out the platter in the first place. The service however was excellent and because I couldn't finish my meal, they immediately packed everything for me as I was ready to go! Overall, nice place to kill some time and try out some beers, but not the most vegetarian friendly place unfortunately.

It's been nearly two years since I moved to SoCal from Philly, and the place I most miss is La Colombe. My days started and ended with La Colombe's cappuccino, enjoyed in either the Rittenhouse Square or the cafe itself. I've found only one other cafe, Cafe Trieste in Berkeley, whose cappuccino matches La Colombe's.

At first, I only studied at La Colombe. (To be honest, I still haven't found another cafe where I feel comfortable studying as I had at La Colombe. Must be something about their seating...) As I became a regular, I found myself drawn into intriguing conversations. La Colombe remains my dream cafe: an excellent team of baristas serving great beverages to interesting patrons studying, reading, doing crossword puzzles, drawing, and engaging in witty conversations.

******************

In reading the reviews thus far, it seems there has been plenty of coverage about the coffee but only mostly negative feedback for the cafe. So here's my lowdown. Decide what you will:

*Opens and closes early: 7am-6pm ish. There are usually a handful of people already waiting at the door before the barista is ready to open. On the weekends!
*The baristas are amazing. The best I've seen anywhere. Incredibly efficient and fast! It helps that most patrons are regulars and know what they want. If you become a regular, the baristas will remember what you usually order and ask you if you want your usual. I varied and hence they never presumed. However, I've seen them notice regular patrons standing in line, serve up their drinks by the time the patrons reach the bar, and off the patrons simply pay and go. It reminded me of a well-choreographed dance. Tip them well if you become a regular. You may get free beverages and useful connections out of it.
*The baristas are all very attractive. They are all people who've other lives, for which networking at La Colombe comes in handy. They know who's who. I consider them to be, to some degree, involved in the weaving of a particular Philadelphian scene. They've never snubbed me. I've never seen them snub anyone. They've always been super professional and discrete.
*There is no menu. Can be intimidating for newcomers and those who like to know how much things cost. Order what you've liked elsewhere. The baristas will make most drinks people would ever want, and they'll let you know if they do not make/have a particular drink/ingredient. Just don't ask for soy milk. Skim is as far as they go. Remember, you're at a cafe owned by a Frenchman. Don't balk at the price. It'll be worth it.
*The iced cappuccino is crack.
*In terms of food, they only offer a limited quantity and variety of pastries. The almond croissants are fantastic. Less a fan of the scones. All can be gone by midday. There's a day (Mon?) when they have no pastries due to logistics. The baristas don't mind at all if you bring your own food. The regulars can be seen eating burgers from Loie's next door.
*Only cash.
*The place can get packed. Then, take your drink to go and stroll through Rittenhouse Square if you were planning on lingering. Or ask someone if you might share a table. People have always been obliging. Then, table hop when one becomes available. I've spent entire afternoons table hopping to my preferred spot or from one conversation to another.
*I tend to see two types of patrons: those who want conversations (i.e. are networking/socializing) and those who want to study. If you plan to study, don't sit near the front. Sit as far away from the bar and door as possible. Generally, although not always, this is where the studious sit whereas those who want conversation, the regulars, choose tables closer to the bar and the door. Invest in noise cancelling headphones, although they'll block out the music but definitely not conversations. If you're an attractive woman or man who comes regularly, the regulars will strike up conversations with you sooner or later. If you don't want that to happen, good luck.
*The baristas and the regulars are characters. Interesting to get to know. Consider yourself warned.

La Colombe Cafe off Rittenhouse Square can be more than just a cafe. Your experience of La Colobme, ultimately, is what you make of it. I chose to make it one of my networks/a scene. Those who prefer otherwise need not. But I do hope you'll really appreciate its contributions to the vitality of Philadelphia.

Never again. I ordered Shrimp and Grits. 5 shrimp , one with a bite out of it. 5 inch bowl with only a quarter inch of grits. With grits selling for $1.95 for 1.5 pounds on Amazon. My guess is only 10¢ worth of grits in the whole bowl. Cost to customer $18.00
This place is extremely overpriced for their McDonald's equivalent food. Bad!! Staff was not pleasant. Food took very long too - avoid if you know what's good for you!

Good place to grab some cajun food.
Found this place on yelp and was intrigued by the bacon grease popcorn, so it was the first thing I ordered. not bad popcorn but it didn't necessarily taste like bacon. I probably wouldn't order again, the Bloodymary's however were incredible, keep them coming! Split a hushpuppy appetizer with friends, they were great and came with two delicious dips.

Ordered the shrimp, Tasso and Grits as my meal, it came with a heaping portion of grits and was delicious! Defiantly had that NOLA kick to it. they were not skimping on the shrimp either!

My favorite thing from the whole menu was the cafe' au Lait. Community Coffee is a NOLA staple, and once I had my first cup years ago I couldn't get enough. It's hard for me to find tho so I jump at the chance whenever I can, even if served with half and half dominating the cup. The waitress bring your mug and pours a steam of community coffee and a stream of half and half at the same time to create a wonderful blend of creamy delicious coffee.
ner_results: {'food': ['bacon grease popcorn', 'hushpuppy appetizer', 'shrimp, Tasso and Grits'], 'drink': ["cafe' au Lait"]}

text: Roti canai, tomyam soup, chicken skewers, singapore-malay style crab. and ABC shaved ice.. Mmmhmm..  I've been coming here for years now, and it still is one of the best Malaysian restaurants that I've been to. I always get roti canai whichever Malay place I go to. Penang does it just right with the right amount of crispiness and thinness. The only thing is the curry could be a bit spicier, but I love the chicken and potato that's in it as well and it isn't runny like other places. When there's leftover, I use it to mix in with my rice. The chicken skewers are delicious with the awesome peanut sauce. Tomyam soup is simple with some vegetables and shrimp and tomyam sauce, but tasty and appetizing as well. We waited patiently for the crabs, which our waiter was very excited to recommend to us. You have to get the Malaysian style special sauce. It's absolutely to die for. It is one giant Alaskan King crab covered in deliciousness! The two of us couldn't even finish it and had to save some for a late-night snack. We also got chicken rice (yellow rice) to accompany it. After all was said and done, ABC shaved ice was much needed to top it all off.
ner_results: {'food': ['Roti canai', 'Chicken skewers', 'Tomyam soup', 'Singapore-Malay style crab'], 'drink': ['ABC shaved ice']}

text: Worst service ever. We didn't feel welcome at all here. They have two floors and the main dining is on the first floor and I guess they have a second floor for when the restaurant gets packed. My parents and I were asked to sit upstairs but nobody was sitting there even though there was a line outside. We were confused and the host just said to us, "Oh you wanna sit down here with us?" Excuse me? That was extremely offensive because it felt like we were being treated differently because of our nationality. Servers and host were definitely friendlier with other tables and it took a while for them to take our order, bring our bill, etc. Food was decent but service absolutely ruined the dining experience. I will never come back.

Let me begin with a disclaimer: I don't eat seafood.

That said, I cannot comment on any of the "real" sushi offerings at Jay's.  I do, however, eat their non-seafood rolls (avacado, sweet potato, fruit, etc) and salads.  Everything is always fresh, the space is very clean, the staff is very friendly, and the prices are very reasonable.

One quibble is that they don't have a "real" kitchen so anything hot is cooked in a toaster oven, which burns. So you'll smell like burnt oil/fish by the time you leave (hold off on going to Jay's until after your meeting).  Also they have a $10 credit card minimum. So bring cash, since it can be difficult to spend 10 bucks in this place.

The service was fantastic. Our server Jordan was very attentive and helpful. He did a great job. The reason I didn't give more stars was for the price and portion. My husband's dish was an amazing black bean burger with fries for $14, while I had a meager harvest salad for $12. It was yummy with blue cheese, pears and pecans, but quite small for $12. I'm well aware of the cost for some of these items but I would have liked to see it either a bit larger or less expensive.

Excellent popcorn, whiskey flight essentially everything including service here was excellent.  I can't wait to come back.  The only issue I had if any was the chicken I ordered was the slightest bit try especially towards the end of the meal.  It wasn't a big deal and it tasted great otherwise so not worth making m a big deal.  Come check it out cuase I think you might really like it.

Went here last night on a saturday weekend of fourth of july. Arrived about 7pm place has about 16 tables and was about 1/2 full. 

The decor is awesome. Its like eating inside a big tent. There are drapes or tapestries on every inch of the walls. 

We had the 7 course feast and enjoyed it alot.  Food came out at a great pace and service was excellent. We had the waiter laughing by the time we left.  I especially liked the lamb with honey. 

This place would be awesome for a group of 4 or more.
Best cannoli I've had in a long time!

4 stars!

I'd heard Honey's name floating about for a while, so on last Saturday morning we went as a group of four to check it out.  I also knew from prior word-of-mouth that it was no reservations and that the line might be long.  When we got there there were people waiting outdoors.  I really liked the fact that Honey provided these heater lamps for the line outdoors - it was about 20F out.  We luckily got to wait just inside the door.. our wait was about 40-45 minutes.  Our waiter filled our coffee really quick and kept it filled our entire time.  Great service.  It was really busy but I never felt like our waiter was overwhelmed.  The menu is extensive and there are lots of options for vegetarians.  Lots of dishes allowed you to sub in tofu or vegetarian sausage.  The portions are generous and I really enjoyed my Enfrijoladas.  Others in the party got the Eastern Omelet, the Sausage with biscuits, and the Breakfast Quesadilla.  I think that everyone agreed that while everything was good, they liked the Quesadilla and the Enfrijoladas the most out of what we got.  I also got a small side of Brussels sprouts with almonds... yummy..

Honey's is also very affordable!  As a side note, I've also heard some things about 'hipsters' going to here often.  I don't usually pay attention to the other guests.. as long as the food is good, I don't care who else is really there.  I don't know if hipsters really make an issue, however, there was some middle aged lady in a fur coat who was also in line and was threatening to kick all the diner's butts, the ones that were leisurely enjoying finishing up their brunch, chatting and drinking coffee.  Then there was another group of 9 (3 were babies) who started giving the host some attitude because they had been made to wait about an hour.  Honey's lay out is such that it's not exactly the best place for large groups.. it's doable but I expect to wait.  There were only about 2 spaces I saw that were really meant for larger groups.  

In short, I'd recommend anyone to come here, but be patient with the possible and likely wait. I'd love to come back sometimes.

Like the other 96% of the population, I love sushi. Like really really love it. If I had the option of eating it for the rest of my life, I would. That being said, I'm always open to trying new sushi restaurants so I was pretty pumped to join my friend for a lovely dinner. Unfortunately, I just wasn't impressed at all. 

Things just started off kind of bad. I got there first, and was welcomed by 3 servers who seemed annoyed that we hadn't made a reservation. That's fair, it was a Saturday night and I probably should've thought that through prior to going. They were able to give us a table, which I definitely appreciated, but they informed me that they needed the table for an 8:30 reservation. Uhm, excuse me? That was just so uncalled for because I spent the entire meal checking the time and feeling like I had to rush out. To be fair, that was the only bad part about the service. Every other aspect about that was superb. The servers were unobtrusive, were very prompt about refilling our water and wine glasses, and were really nice too. 

For the prices that they were charging, I expected the food to be out of this world and frankly, it wasn't. The maki roll that I ordered (I think it was the Paradiso roll?) was extremely salty, which is saying a lot since I salt EVERYTHING. The seaweed salad was SUPER fishy, which makes sense since yeah, it's seaweed, but I guess I'm just partial to the regular, not fancy kind. The sushi and sashimi combination dish that we got was infinitely better, but I feel like I could've had that same quality of dish elsewhere for cheaper. The one dish that stood out the most was the rock shrimp tempura with a wasabi aioli. It was PHENOMENAL. It wasn't super greasy and the tempura remained crisp the entire time, despite being tossed in the aioli. I would be tempted to go back again for that alone. 

Izumi, I really wanted to like you. It sucks living in South Philly because there isn't any sushi down here at all, and going to Vic's isn't always an option. But your food just isn't worth the price. Sorry :/

Oh, and as for all those reservations that made the servers tell us about needing the table for 8:30? The restaurant was half-empty when we left at 8:15.
ner_results: {'food': ['maki roll', 'seaweed salad', 'sushi and sashimi combination dish'], 'drink': []}

text: We came over from Constitution Hall because of an afternoon shower. The only thing that was prompt was my check. It took 10 minutes or more for water, longer for food and and drinks. We could see our food sitting there waiting for an eternity it felt like ....for the waiter to pick it up.  I was hoping for better because the place looks so nice.

This place has been delivering consistent delicious food and wine at incredible prices. They staff is always well trained. In fact no mater who is working the staff is always accommodating and I appreciate that!

I eat at Richie's M-W-F before my early morning class and sometimes a quick lunch when I'm in a hurry and I'm such a fan. The food is always freshly made, the service is fast, and Richie always knows my order when I come to the window.  It's an A+ in my book.

No more food? 

I was there just last year. The desserts are amazing, especially the chocolate cuban cigar with candy matches. 

The atmosphere is amazing and chic. Almost an European (because of the lounges) feel but more Cuban. Less music than Bongos!

I came here for lunch a while ago with my sister and had a lovely time. I was a little surprised at the price range of this place, given that the decor and the type of food of this place doesn't seem that high end or of 'fine dining' caliber. If I had some money to spare, and I wanted a relaxing, beautiful, yet casual meal, I'd come here - especially for a girl-friends date.

My sister and I shared the crispy artichokes for our appetizer. It wasn't very large, from what I remembered, but it was delicious, especially the lemony sauce it came with. It wasn't such a let down that the appetizer was small though, since we ordered a whole pizza to share between the two of us. It came out on a silver pizza platter, which the waitress balanced on an large, antique-y looking tomato can. I'm not sure why - perhaps to save table space - but it was still a charming presentation. We had a pizza with cippolini on it, so I'm assuming it's the mushroom pizza. It was great! We loved all the ingredients together on it, and we demolished the entire thing. For dessert, we shared an affagato - I think vanilla ice cream in espresso, if I remember correctly. It was a fitting end to the meal.

We came when it was not so busy and when the weather was lovely enough to sit outside, to be in full view of the river. Maybe avoid if it gets packed. I would definitely bring a few girls here for brunch or lunch on a beautiful day to have a laid back yet classy meal.
I really liked the trendy space and the food was pretty good as well. All of the food I tried was pretty good but not amazing.
Great Philly cheese "steaks" and great French fries. Great for it being fast too. The friend with me eats meat and couldn't believe it wasn't meat.

Great food and even better service.

Went with my parents and my boyfriend - so the small table was a little cramped.  The boys ordered a martini and when the waiter came over to bring my mother's drink - he spilled one of the two martinis.  Immediately he apologized, gave us another free martini (and comp'd the spilled one) and gave us a free appetizer.  Couldn't get much better than that.

Had the meatballs, anchovies, and roasted peppers - delicious.  Everyone else loved their food too (eggplant parm, veal and peppers, sausage and peppers).  If you want home style Italian food - go there.

Only problem is that the valet was basically non-existent so I say park yourself.

I stayed in the Loews Hotel June 30th to July the first, for my Bf's birthday. The room was okay, nothing spectacular. The pool was average, no hot tub. But my main complaint is check out was at 11, we left and an hour late I remembered I left my bathing suit in the room hanging with the towels in bathroom. When I called the hotel to report my left item and try and pick it up I was given the run around for about 3 days. First I was transferred to loss prevention who took my number and told me he was going to check the room and call me back immediately. In an hour there was no follow up, so I asked my boyfriend who the room was in his name to call, when he called he was told he didn't speak to anyone about a bathing suit and my BF should call after five bc that's when they bring left items down. He calls again at five and is told he will be called in the morning, fast forward to the morning, no call. He calls they say the girl who cleaned the room isn't there or something and they have to wait until tomorrow to interview the cleaning lady & someone is in our room therefore they can't look. By Monday he had to call one final time after them constantly promising to follow up and reach out and just offered to reimburse me. I don't understand how someone could get into the room without my. Bathing suit being seen, it was in plain sight. I would not stay here again just based off of the horrible customer service they gave me when it came to retrieving my item.

Seriously love this place. They're iced coffee is extra strength with expresso made into it, which I truly appreciate because I add expresso to my iced coffee always. They also have kermits bake goods which is just amazing.

1925 is quite a unique lounge for Philadelphia. They renovated what used to be the old G lounge to throwback to a different time. I went here on heir opening night as a friend of mine knew one of the investors.
When you walk downstairs you are greeted by beautiful women who check your ID and coat. Their attire is sexy and maybe not be what a lot of people expect but this lounge is all about the experience. As
you move in further you feel like you're thrown into the set of The Great Gatsby. The music is a great remix of classics and top 40. There is plenty of space for large groups and to mingle with new people.
They mean for this lounge to be for the rich and successful (or really if you feel like dropping $100+ easily for a couple of drinks and small plates). The crowd is 30+.
The special drink menu has been carefully crafted although limited. Be warned that there aren't any prices on the menu but I can't imagine it's anything less than the ballpark of $20 per drink. Try the Fitzgerald and the Coco Chanel.
What separates this lounge from the others in the city are the dancers. Yes they are glittery, scantily clad women but it's all a part of the show this place presents. You get the whole package of ambiance, drinks, and entertainment.

Diamond in the rough, restaurant in the furniture showroom...

The friendly waitstaff took good care of us and were flexible when part of our party canceled at the last minute. Everything we tried was good; including the Saumon (salmon), Canard (duck), and Bavette (hanger steak). Definitely come at least for a drink and the impressive view of the river and West Philly, but also give the food a try!
I had the Bella burger on arugula. It was the best portobello mushroom I have ever had to eat! Busy but efficient and friendly staff. Was able to get a table and enjoy my salad immediately.

Okay, I'll give them another star. I've been back a few times since my original review (thanks to Square sending me a half-price coupon to entice me to return), and the quality has definitely picked up. I've only re-tried the Spicy Philly Panini since my last review, but each time it has been tasty, fresh, and satisfying--and now it even comes with bacon! I accidentally discovered that it's even better on the sizzler bread when they were out of the panini bread one day, so that's how I will be ordering it from now on.

Their paninis still feel a tad bit expensive when they don't come with chips or anything on the side, but the last couple I've gotten have been substantial enough to justify the cost, unlike when I got them before and still felt hungry.

It's been a different set of people making food and taking orders, at least during the lunchtimes I've stopped by, and they're all really nice. The previous employees were all really nice, too, but this crew seems to be more on top of the details and maintaining quality control. So, they're back in my lunch rotation for now!

Decent, clean, but it didn't wow me. That's okay though. I went in because I've heard others talk about it and I've never been. So me and my lady wanted to try a new pub for drinks and a pubfood and this is where we ended up. I had the Reuben and she had the burger and we shared some of the curry fries. Both the sandwiches were too large to finish in one sitting, but that's okay by me. I love leftovers for lunch. The fries were "interesting". I lived in England for a little while so when I saw curry fries on the menu I immediately was brought back. The fries I remember were nothing like the fries I got, but that doesn't mean they were bad. The Reuben was a Reuben. Nothing crazy... The burger though... That was a mean burger. It was enormous, and they had great toppings choices. She went with the goat cheese and caramelized onions. They went a little overboard with the goat cheese but otherwise it was a good burger. 

It was a little better than meh, but it wasn't enough to lure me from my other favorite pubs. I'd go back though. 


Oh, one more thing. We ate upstairs and the bartender who waited on us was a sweetheart.

I came here with a bunch of friends for dinner. The place was pretty much empty. We ordered the meat lover's pizza pie and the spring pizza pie. I ate the meat lover's pie and it was alright. I wish I tried the other pizza because it looks good. The fries were okay, nothing to write about. I think this place is good since their menu is large and has speciality pizzas that are affordable. I would come here again and try a different pizza.

I frequent this place often. The drinks are great, the food is always satisfying, the staff is pleasant, the owner is charismatic and even jumps in and gets her hands dirty with her staff when it's busy. It has a good vibe too. Staff always greets customers. Overall, I like this place, I like the people, I love the food. The portions look small but it's filling. Benna's, B2, and Benna's West are all neighborhood hits!!

The best coffee on the east coast, if not in the country. 

I've never had any attitude from the baristas, and I'm wondering what exactly would warrant this treatment. I've had nothing but polite and helpful service.

Over rated!!! The best thing about the restaurant was the view! First when we arrived I knew we where in for a great meal but to my surprise I was extremely dissatisfied. One of the people in my party ordered a cup of tea which never came. I ordered my meal specifically without pearl onions, pearl onions where all throughout the dish. I had to eat my dinner alone because by the time my meal came out the correct way they where all finished. Now to the taste, all of our meals where overly salted!!! The lobster bisque runs you $14 and comes with about .50 worth of lobster!!!! The portion sizes where very small not worth the price at all. Even at your standard franchise restaurant a manager comes to your table if there is an issue, not here. My food came out piping hot and I was rushed to eat it because the rest of my party was waiting. We wanted this to be special for my brothers 50th birthday but he was disappointed.

You, always so solid with your guacamole made to order, and a "perfect margarita" that is all that. I always want to be tempted further along your menu, but two finely crafted beverages usually push me into "check please."

I have been meaning to submit a review for Eatalia and feel bad I haven't done this sooner! 

I went to dinner with a few friends to Eatalia and consider myself an EXTREMELY picky eater.  I was a little skeptical because I had yet to hear about the place and it's a little off the beaten path.  However, if I would recommend any Italian restaurant in the city, this would be one of them.  I have been to La Viola, Gnocchi, Porcini, Modo Mio, and all of the top Italian restaurants and I can honestly say the food here definitely competes with all of them.  

We started with the antipasta and I assure you it was extremely good and had an excellent variety.  Next was the crabcake.  I am extremely picky about crabcakes but this was EXCELLENT! Nice crisp outside and juicy lump crabmeat inside.  Definitely one of the best I have ever had.  From there, I had the Filet Mignon in a Fra Diavalo sauce.  I am sitting here today writing the review while craving their Fra Diavalo sauce.  EXCELLENT!

We finished off with the Tiramasu and loved it.  They also definitely get points for the presentation!

I think the difference between Eatalia and all of the other Philadelphia Italian BYOBs is that it really conveys that small, intimate setting that you crave when you go to an Italian restaurant.  The owner is waiting on tables, meeting with customers and makes you feel at home.   You feel welcome and are not just "another" customer!  You can definitely tell that they are passionate about what they do!  

This is definitely the type of place I see myself going to weekly to have dinner with family & friends.  

If you are looking for a diamond in the rough, this is your place!! I'm just upset I didn't know of this place sooner!
Delicious pastries with a quirky South Philly ambiance.  I always get the powdered ricotta doughnut.  It's like a cannoli/doughnut love child!

Coventry Deli is perfect for those days at work when you have zero clue what it is you might want to eat. The deli offers a little bit of everything: sandwiches, salads, pastries, hot meals, etc. 
My favorite meal: grilled cheese and a cup of the chili of the day. yummm. 
They have a lot of specials depending on the day of the week, so this is definitely worth a try. For the price, it really can't be beat.
This place has most delicious crepes in Philly!!! Love there Philly crepe, Caramel Ricotta crepe and La Colombe coffee!! Love love love!!!
Loveeeee this place can't even count how many times I been here. Food is always good and fresh. I live in MD and whenever I'm in Philadelphia I can't leave without stopping here first!

text: The Passero's in Suburban Station is my everyday go-to. They are always unfailingly nice, very quick and efficient, and their coffee is fantastic! Also the quality of their coffee and other drinks comes at a better price than any other boutique coffee shop in the area. I know Philly lives on DD but if you're looking for quality coffee and service at only a fraction more of the price, Passero's is absolutely worth it. Small varietal every morning for me!

Perhaps we caught them on an off night. It was late, so I understand why the waitstaff was less attentive than normal. After speaking with the bar tender (when I got up from my dinner table to get a drink since the waiter hadn't asked if I wanted a refill after 25 minutes of an empty glass) I was told that the waiter actually lied about not having my selection in stock. 

Did I mention the $4 up-charge for ordering my single malt scotch neat? How else is it supposed to be served? 

Steak was medium plus. I asked for medium rare. Unacceptable for a $55 steak. Sure, I could ask for another, but then then rest of my table would have finished before I received my meal. I don't mind paying for a quality meal. This however, was not.

Found this spot randomly. Best Greek food I have ever had. We tried the dip of the day, chicken kabab, sampler platter, and the vegetarian pie. All excellent and our guests were impressed as well. New flavors and sooo fresh! We will definitely be back to try the vegetarian sampling dinner.
Walking in there gave you a nice vibe. The service was great and the  food was pretty good!

This simple family restaurant, with its friendly and solicitous service, is a good place to satisfy one's hankering for Indonesian home-style food.  The menu covers pretty much all the standard dishes subsumed under the catch-all term "Indonesian" and is broadly divided into noodle and rice plates, some organized in the fashion of a (modest) colonial Dutch rijstafel (a style of eating that allowed for sampling food from different areas).

We started with the egg noodle dish Mie Komplit, a combination plate that included BBQ pork, shredded chicken, vegetables, and eggs (hard boiled).  Rice platters we tried included the Rendang beef platter and a combination platter of various meats and vegetables.  The noodles were nicely prepared, as was the rice, and the diverse accompaniments tasty, if of somewhat differing quality (the pork belly had been around for a while).  The soups that came with these plates had a clean but thin chicken taste.  One minor quibble I have is that the temperature of the food was not as hot as I would have liked it to be.

All this delectable eating comes at astonishingly low prices.  The tea served is hot and always quickly replenished with another pot, the ice coffee serviceable.  The attentiveness and generosity of the service must be mentioned here again, maybe that is one of the reasons, besides the home-spun food, that so many Indonesian families eat at Sky Cafe.

text:
I don't know maybe my expectations were set to high or I have to high of standards but I was underwhelmed when we went here for brunch yesterday. 

Major points to the staff who were nice enough to accommodate my crazy rescheduling of times of our reservation and service was nice as well. 

But the food just wasn't anything amazing. It was good but lacked seasoning.
I got the chicken and waffles which the waffle & bourbon syrup were very tasty but the chicken itself was lacking in any seasoning. Not even salt & pepper.

I also tried the chorizo & scrambled egg quesadilla and it had the same issue of being pretty bland. We expected the chorizo to give it some heat but it really didn't which was disappointing. 

Like I said maybe my expectations were set to high by all of the praise or maybe it is just that brunch items are not their strong suit. I will probably come back for a dinner to give them another chance because I really want them to be as good as everyone says so I guess I'll update this review at some point in the future.

I know five stars is a lot for a burger place, but bare burger deserves some credit for being different and original. I loved all the choices of burgers including bison and elk. The fries were really tasty as well which is promising for a place that serves burgers. There was a good selection of beer and other hard drinks. I order the ice cream cookie sandwich for dessert and it blew me away with how good it was. Like I said before I know it is not the fanciest place in Philly, but it was a nice change of pace from fast food burgers and chain restaurants.

I honestly love this place me and my boyfriend go all the time ,  but It gets very crowded to the point sometimes I feel the server forgets about us ( we've sat for a while without ordering before someone realized we were there and that's weird because they seat you )  .  This has happened on more then one occasion & not only to us . If the food weren't so good we probably wouldn't come back . Me and my boyfriend are big foodies . The shrimp tacos are especially delicious especially if you like spicy food . The drinks are made really  well we always grab drinks when we go . My boyfriend loves the burgers . I love the tacos and the pulled pork sandwich . They just need to get better or more servers or maybe a better system . I know it's probable not the servers fault because they probably get a bunch of tables but I think everyone deserves great service .

My favorite C&P's location. The service isn't always great but there's so much room and seating, you really never need to wait for a table. Love their crab and sweet potato fries combo, they give you his maple dipping sauce. It's so tasty! The wings, cutlets, mussels, and pizza are all good. They have such a huge draft selection and they have daily specials. We went before a Phillies game and was able to make happy hour. $4 craft draft beers, $5 white or pepperoni pizza. Delicious!!!

text:
Nice view restaurant. We were welcome downstairs by a nice gentleman, and he got the elevator for us to go to the 37th floor. Looks like the rest of the building is for condominiums or offices, which require key cards to get in. 
Upon arrival upstairs, we were warmly greeted by two lovely ladies. And we got seated to our reserved window table. 
The view is very nice. The first thing we noticed is Philadelphia is flat. No hills, and no fog like San Francisco. A bit hazy, or is it pollution? 
Taylor was our server, she was extremely professional and courteous and friendly. The supporting staff too, but we failed to get their names. A lady we guessed was the manager came by and checked on how we were enjoying our meal too. 
The oysters were from Nova Scotia, and nothing to rave about. No flavor, no sweetness like Kumamoto or Kushi, or Malpeque.. we liked the hors d' oeuvres, compliments of the chef. It was something like a sea salt lavash bread with avocado. Very nice. 
The lobster looked good, but no dipping sauce and no lemon till we asked. The bone in rib eye was cooked to the desired temperature, but too fatty. This was not from a well marbled meat, it was just plain too much fat. The truffle sabayon was excellent though. The curry fingerling potatoes were good, the lobster Mac and cheese was over cooked, the cheese was a puddle of grease. 
We ordered the warm vanilla cake for dessert. Just great presentation, but meh on the taste. 
The pictures on Yelp were quite different from what we got. Could it be the kitchen was not up to standard tonight. Nevertheless, the excellent service and the view made up for the average but pricey meal.

The "flagship" Wawa is a joke. It's always filthy, they're always out of various items, and it's attracted a very shady crowd (thank god there's always cops here). Homeless people and "One Step Away newspaper" are always right outside ready to bother you for your change. I've actually been insulted by one of the homeless men after I wouldn't engage him when he bothered me (he actually wasn't asking for change).

Now, why, in a city with some of the best restaurants would someone choose to eat here unless they were across the street? The food is on par with that of a hospital cafeteria.

Believe the hype. The best donuts you will ever have. Dense, cakey, moist, and hot n fresh. Run, don't walk!
P.S. Matt H has rated Papa Johns 5 stars and Wawa 1 star, sooo...
The food in their side restaurant is awesome. Great Italian food and a great atmosphere. We have many work lunches there and the staff is always very attentive!

I went here a couple of months ago for breakfast on a Friday morning and was disappointed as this is usually such a great place. The menu selection was underwhelming and not as large as I hoped for. There was some early morning drama going on with the wait staff and you could really feel that energy. My server made another server cry and she stormed outside and was being consoled by a third server. I could also hear them all talking about the incident and discussing whose fault it was and overall was just a weird morning and pretty hard to focus on the group I was with. I honestly probably wouldn't go back after the last experience although previously I have enjoyed it.

More good stuff then few little bad things. Lobby and lounge/bar are nice. Bit pricey but decent food and drink options. 

Room was nice. Bed was nice and sturdy. Tested that bad boy out a lot. 

Drain in shower was slow/blocked up last time I showered. Not that big of a deal but annoying. 

Location is great. Was here for a wedding and central location was nice, but my truck would not fit in underground parking.

Doughy "hush puppies" with no clams or even clam flavor!  Heavy, bland.  Don't get this loser.  Wife liked her crabcakes and the roasted cabbage is tasty.

text: I ordered the Pad Thai and a side of brown rice, figuring that the Pad Thai wouldn't be enough for dinner. I was wrong. The Pad Thai was quite filling and very good. Penang is a great take out option if you are staying at a Chinatown area hotel.

Have been here a few times, both for snacks/drinks at the bar and for a sit down meal. I've enjoyed both experiences. I really like University City and am always happy to find another worthwhile eatery in an ever evolving section of the city. The interior is very homey and relaxing. I've been treated very well by the bartender and when we ate at a table the service was good as well, even with my 2 year old along. As far as the food goes, the guacamole is very tasty, the salsa fresh and spicy and I love the thin tortilla chips. They're well worth the couple extra dollars. Main dishes are good too. There's more authentic Mexican dishes as well as some of the regular Americanized classics. All were very good. The sides (rice and/or beans) were a touch on the bland side. I wouldn't consider the prices to be cheap, but they're not outrageous. It's been empty every time I've been which I hope is not a sign of things to come. I'm looking forward to my next visit.

Everything is okay, however, which one thing made me very disappointed was one time, they changed the amount of money which I put on the reciept. After that I check my online banking statement everytime after going there to make sure they don't have this problem anymore. text:
I like the food.  Its not impressive, but its good if you want a little something.  The food is consistent, so is the terrible service.   I have been there at least a dozen times because my husband likes one of their plates and every time we went, there was always a problem.  

First off, if you get there as they are opening, the manager will make you stand outside regardless of the temperature until he feels like opening - regardless of their posted hours.  On several occasions, they walked away with our drinks when there was half still left, then asked if we want another one.  Its clear that they find every way possible to increase the size of your bill.  Another time, I asked if they would mix  soda water with juice in a glass and when the bill came, I was charged for a glass of each.

Recently, their new talent has been bringing one entree (mine), then once its finished, taking the plate and silverware, then bringing my husband's a solid half hour later.  By the way, we both ordered tacos, and other than us, the place was empty.  We were offered drinks to make up for the "confusion" which we were double charged for.  

This place has potential if they can only get the employees to get their acts together and their fingers out of my wallet.  As for me, I make no secret of the fact that its a terrible place to be.

This is my all time favorite place to frequent for breakfast or lunch, when my two girlfriends and I need to do some catching up.

I've tried a handful of items off their breakfast and lunch menu.  Items that I have tried off the top of my head are:
Huevos Rancheros -absolutely delicious! 
Mahi Mahi Tacos - love the slaw and sauce on top.
Challah French Toast - good and with a twist of citrus.
Veggie Omelet - delicious and cheesy.
Chocolate Chip pancakes - so chocolately and fluffy.

As mentioned by other reviewers, the wait is long if you get there during their peak hours for lunch, so get there early.  Parking can be a pain as well, but definitely come give it a try!

text: What hasn't been said about Vetri?  I can't add much, but I must say it is the perfect meal; from the food, to the ambiance, to the service.  A must try for every Philadelphian.  The stand out dishes for our table seemed to be the snails, onion crepe, gnocchi, and lamb.
Excellent burgers and sandwiches! Only got 4 stars instead of 5 bc the food is a la carte  and it's an extra 3 bucks for fries. It's all a bit pricey but definitely tasty. Great service.
Try the fish with the rice & beans with fish gravy...YUM!!! Everything that I tasted from here was very good

Too pricey, too slow, too small for the price. The burgers - which do not come cheap - are ridiculously tiny. You can frequent similar burger bars that use grass fed, organic foods and receive a much greater bang for your buck. 

The service was also awful. Waitstaff were dismissive and harried. But the most shocking issue was the lack of water on a 95 degree day. We asked for more and the waitress took our bottle; ten minutes later, we asked another and he said he'd get some. Neither did. We asked a few minutes later and were told there was no cold water.

She dropped our check and left without a word. Simply awful. Jon is moving up to Philly soon and we LOVE burgers - but we definitely won't be here again.

Really great restaurant from top to bottom. Ambiance, food, service, the works. I have eaten at a lot of great restaurants and this compared very very well with more expensive places I have eaten at in NYC or San Francisco. I am always a fan of the prix fixe - like variety and not having to make choices. Definitely worth checking out.

We visited Square 1682 at 1:30pm for lunch on Friday of restaurant week.  It was not very crowded, which was good because the tables were practically on top of one another.  Besides the close seating the place was nice and comfortable while still feeling trendy.  The plates and mugs were pretty cool too - oblong shapes and interesting designs.

For apps, we split the lemon hummus and the petit salad.  I was bummed that the roasted squash soup that I saw on the online menu didn't make any reference to it having lobster in it.  Bummer.  The salad was boring.  The dressing was sweet and pleasant but other meh.  The hummus was delicious and the presentation in a glass jar with lemons was particularly attractive.  And I loved that there was a good amount of pita.  We also got bread, butter, and some really tasty dipping oil (though there was very, very little of it).

He got the creative It's Always Sunny Chicken Sandwich which has a crispy chicken breast, sunny side up egg, frisée, bacon-soy vinaigrette, and garlic parmesan fries.  There were two veg options: a roasted vegetable sandwich and a vegetable lasagna.  I was warned that the vegetable lasagna isn't a standard lasagna - there are no noodles or cheese, it's more like a thinly layered napoleon.  I went with this as I felt I could get a veggie sandwich anywhere.

His arrived on a big plate and looked really interesting.  He said it was good and the fries were quite nice as well.  

My face kind of dropped when mine arrived as it was a tiny square of layered vegetables and a small side of tabouleh.  Looking at some of the other tables, most meals were generous.  Mine was not.  At all.  It tasted fine, a little spicy actually, but otherwise just fine.  

We ordered the Café con Leche Panna Cotta and Apple Cider Fritters.  Both were solid, though the fritters were just two small balls with some ice cream.  The panna cotta was more substantial.

All around a good meal but I don't think I'd revisit it any time soon.  Just not the right place for this vegetarian.

text: Finally got around to trying Zaika today.  Food was very good; however it was a bit difficult to tell initially as the spice level was definitely not even along the same scoville scale as I ordered.  Way too hot for mild.  That said the food was tasty and portions ample, more than enough for two or three or maybe four, which was really challenging for me as I'm the only Indian food lover in the house, so I will be eating vegetable Biryani for weeks.   I got take out and the young woman who waited on me was helpful and absolutely delightful.  I will definitely be going back, but will choice other less heat provoking options.  Than you Yelpers of a good recommendation.

Morton's is solid, but extremely overpriced. My family and I went to the Philadelphia location for my dad's birthday 1.) because he loves steakhouses 2.) he's a Morton's member and they gave him a $100 gift card.

The location is great, right off of Broad on Walnut Street, but the interior needs major renovation. I felt like I was back in the 90's in this place, and it just looked tired.

I also don't like that they bring out that cart of raw meat and fish to explain their menu and the specials. First, the whole demonstration took about 10 minutes and we were thirsty and starving. I also don't like looking at raw meat covered in plastic wrap that has been sitting out for a while. NOT appetizing.

My strip steak was good, but I have to say that the $8 one I purchased at reading terminal and broiled at home was just as satisfying.

The creamed spinach was excellent compared to other steakhouses like The Palm, and my cucumber drink with St. Germain was absolutely delicious. The breaded shrimp in beurre blanc appetizer was forgettable, as was the chopped salad and asparagus with bernaise.

They gave us a free molten chocolate cake for dessert and it was terrible. Very commercial tasting. I've had better with a Duncan Hines mix.

Go here if you're on an expense account or have a gift card. Otherwise, patronize local places like Union Trust or Butcher and Singer.

text: Local place that serves up awesome food. I've been for brunch a lot, and dinner a few times. The food never disappoints. The blue duck fries are a staple that we order every time we go. This time they had cheese curds as one of their specials. They were lightly fried in a tempura like batter and had a hint of jalapeno in them, so awesome. We also ordered the carrot cake with hazelnut ice cream, so delicious.

Delicious, authentic Indonesian food. We had the kwetiau goreng and lontong sayur. Both were generous portions and brought back memories of Indonesia. Having lived in Medan, Indonesia for 9 months, I was thrilled to discover that the owners are from Medan. Definitely trying the nasi campur Medan next time!  I highly recommend this place to anyone who misses Indonesia or just wants some Indonesian food.

Being a vegetarian, people wonder why I like Village Whiskey.  Primarily, there's whiskey, of which I am a fan.  Anyone I take there who's not a vegetarian is a fan of the burgers.  And finally, the veggie burger is tasty, even though it tends to fall apart while you're eating it.  Went there with the bf on a Sunday evening.  We were seated immediately, which is a rarity at this venue.  Bf had a cheeseburger and I had the veggie burger.  We also got fries with cheddar sauce, although the sauce wasn't as flavorful as we wanted for a sauce made from actually cheddar.  Maybe they should have used a sharper cheese.  We also had milkshakes.  Bf had the cherry garces and I had the blueberry one.  Both were good, but the cherry was very sweet.  Though you'll end up spending a little more here than at your regular burger place, the ambience makes up for it.  Good place for after dinner libations as well.

Amazing meal and service!! They serve Certified Angus Beef which is THE BEST!! We had steaks which were cooked to perfection, sides of roasted veggies, amazing. Service over the top!! Drinks delicious! This is one of the hidden gems of Philly! Look forward to returning

Wrapped in hot foil, soft
cheese melts between egg and roll
I fly satisfied

Been a grab and goer at La Colombe since high school and I love it (for the art, for those crazy foreign regulars, for the baristas, for the decor, for the mugs and, of course, for the coffee) to this day.

Hate to hear complaints about the baristas. I know it has that whole "sizes? scoff" vibe, but that's part of the charm, and every time I've seen a barista run down the no menu no sizes deal to a new customer it's been very polite - but honestly, as I've worked in the service industry, I'd be annoyed having to recite it all the time too. I've actually seen customers react like spoiled children when they were calmly told there were no flavors besides mocha.

Anyway, everyone goes through that awkward first time paying their "uh, can I get a medium ice coffee with a shot?" dues, and from there on out one can confidently and condescendingly participate in that oh-so-Rittenhouse chichi coffee culture. And feel good about it.

One thing I do wonder about though - how on earth can all those seemingly homeless people afford $4 cappuccinos?

I tried their cold brew on Tap. I wanted their cold brew latte on tap but they ran out... It was only 2:30 on a Sunday. This coffee shop is pretty sweet. Honestly, the atmosphere is pretty nice. Although it is very crowded. There were a lot of people there.

It seems like its not easy to grab a table. Definately come check it out.

Ah, Makiman, my favorite superhero. Defender of Justice, always ready to roll at the first sign of anything fishy. (Sorry, I'll not stop with the puns now.) 

Firstly, it's BYOB, so bring your favorite boxed wine that pairs well with sushi (I hear this year's vintage of Franzia is excellent). The servers will graciously bring you some ice and some glasses when you get there. 

The food is very good. We started with the tuna nachos. Yes, you read that correctly. I can't recommend these enough. They were made up fresh, raw tuna chopped up in a spicy sauce on top of a crispy chip (I think you get 4 chips). Each one is pretty big and delicious. Seriously, get these. They also have a huge roll selection with some pretty creative options. I think we had the Viking Roll and a few others. Also, the rolls are very reasonably priced compared to other sushi places. 

So thank you, Makiman, for everything you do for this great metropolis.

Nothing is bad at the menu, I was going to put up a bad review just to make less people come here but that's selfish of me. The latkes make grizzled warriors break down in tears. The eggs are eggcellent

Drinks: 4
Decor: 3
Ambiance: 3.5
Service: 3.5
Value: 2.5

This seems like a great neighborhood bar, unfortunately it isn't my neighborhood. I'm not sure I would venture out of my way to go there as a destination, but you could certainly do worse. They have a great draft beer selection, and a good assortment of snacks.

I went here on a Sunday night, so it wasn't too crowded with tourists. I ordered a turkey sandwich and mixed green salad. The turkey sandwich was tasty, but pretty small. I don't remember seeing nouveau in front of the sandwich description.  The mixed green salad was fresh and the vinaigrette was tangy. However, the salad fit on the smallest plate available, which is to say it was almost microscopic in size. Frankly the meal just wasn't worth the money. I'd rather have gone to Potbelly's or Top Tomato across the street. The only good thing about the place was that there were a lot of good looking women studying there.

My cousin had her wedding here last spring, and it was so beautiful here! The indoor and outdoor facilities are very nice, and their lawns are beautifully manicured. 

I was impressed by the size of the facility, which can hold over 200 people (at least). There was an outdoor cocktail reception and indoor dinner reception. 

The hors d'oeuvres were delicious, my favorite being the beef wellingtons! 

My cousin has impeccable taste. I was pleasantly surprised with the decor and dinner service. My guess is that I ate a mixed greens salad with rasberries and feta cheese with a vinaigrette..... i could be wrong, but it all melded together so well. There was also a choice of steak, fish or vegetarian. I opted for the steak. See the pictures! I Love potatoes so it was perfect for me.... steak, potatoes au gratin and snow peas.

Great venue!

Omg! Where to begin??!! First off the whole vibe of Honeys is very cool- laid back, hipster with good music and outstanding food! They have fresh ingredients and combinations you wouldn't think of like challah bread French toast stuffed with cheesy eggs and baked ham. But the good isn't weird or snobby like some of the new American kind. It's different but grounded and delicious! I had eggs my way - fried over hard perfectly, the ham was yummy but not too salty and the biscuit- oh lord- sooooooo good! Plus they make their own preserves! My husband had the country fried steak with eggs and a latke yum! He moaned the entire time eating it lol the breeding was outstanding and the latke was yummy and crispy. Overall good vibe good people and outstanding food! A must try!!!!

text:
It's a really cute place for breakfast in the Northern Liberties section of Philly.  This morning I was there for a medical appointment, and I wanted to take advantage of some of the more quaint things to do in Philly that weren't right in Center City.

They have an extremely charming atmosphere, and you can see it in all the touches here and there.  Breakfast items are all fairly creative, but not too snobby.  The service is quick and efficient, but I noticed that they just were not overly chatty.  I like how they have a food runner, which many smaller establishments don't have, so the plates come out as soon as they are ready.

Ironically, the last time I had grits was in Mississippi, so I can't say that I enjoyed the grits I had here.  But that might not be fair to say.

Wow, this is some pretty good pizza.  Technique wise it was obviously cooked very quickly in a very hot oven (though to nitpick, it was a tiny bit too charred).  The crust and toppings were top notch for both flavor and quality.

Likely the best pizza in Philadelphia (yes, at least as good as if not better than Osteria).

Came here for drinks for a friend's birthday. Kenny was the absolute best bartender and the drinks were phenomenal. The guys loved their whiskey drinks and I loved my extra dirty martinis. He was so knowledgeable and fun. We had such a great time and are so excited to come back!

My bf took me to Fez for my birthday last year. Not bad.... we had chicken with olives. (Very tender!!!! )  It was dark as I-don't-know-what, inside the restaurant and I could BARELY see my menu!!!  I can tell you this, though.... I didn't eat everything that was brought out to me! 

I ate the bread and salad, but didn't care much for the vegetable cous-cous. I enjoyed my mint tea and pastries.... and loved that steamed  towels were brought out to us in between each course to clean your hands. 

We also got a hookah. I took a few puffs and didn't think it was anything special, since I'm not a smoker. 

Would I go again? Not sure. The atmospohere was cool and fun, but the food was nothing special. Also the belly-dancer had clearly seen better days, and it was pretty annoying the way she lingered at my table until my bf tipped her. LOL

I came here several times always takes me to wait. I just order a pick up, I still need to wait after I arrived. From placed order to actual pick up nearly an hour. I don't know why. Also they provided bad service and bad attitude. My order is ready by they didn't tell me I can pick up. They let me wait half hour. So sad of their service. I would like give them no star!!
So Good.!So Good. So Good. So Good. The food is insanely good. The burrito is huge. The wait time is fast.

Went here b/c of a Groupon deal, all the tables in my area had Groupons so they must be having trouble bringing in diners.
Went on a 3/1, Friday during Lent....out of hard shell crabs unless I wanted the garlic kind. What??!! this is a crab restaurant and you're out of crabs.
I don't think the waitress told us about any specials, the menu didn't wow me. King crab legs were way too pricey for this place too, I almost didn't have anything  to select. Ordered appetizer of stuffed mushrooms, these were good not great.
 One of my party ordered soda, came from the bar, 1st glass was good, the next flat as a pancake, he asked for a replacement and it was just as bad...how do you get a soda wrong?
No one brought us any bread, rolls or oyster crackers to munch on while we waited for our food. Our meals were broiled platter combinations and were just ok.
I used to like dining here, it used to be much busier. Maybe they should update the decor a bit, its so old, dirty and dated.
Not worth the parking lot fee we had to pay to eat here.

The people who work here are super friendly and the food came out before I was able to refresh my Facebook page.  The place is mostly takeout with a few tables for eating in and the decor is stylish with bright green high back booths, clear stools and lots of gerber daisies.  

I came here 2 days in a row because it was on my way home, I was feeling lazy and wanted to eat something healthy.  The first day I came in I got the udon noodle salad and the green lemonade.  The salad was delicious, but it came with arugula which I hate, and it wasn't listed anywhere in the description.  The green lemonade with kale juice and agave necter was delicious and refreshing and not too sweet.  The 2nd day I decided to try the jerk ceasar salad.  The salad was a little boring and the jerk chick'n pieces were kind of bland.  It was basically like morningstar fake chicken thrown over some romaine lettuce leaves with some 'crispy plantains' which I thought would be real plantains, not 2 plantain chips.  The creamy island spiced dressing that came with the salad was awesome.  If they sold that in bottles I would definitely get some.  The groothie smoothie was also pretty good with apples, bananas, and unidentified 'leafy greens.' 

Next time I'll have to try the hipcity ranch sandwich which I hear is like fake fried chicken and is delicious..  Overall, the place is definitely a vast improvement from the not so good food and bitchy service of the former Pad Thai Shak.

text:
Pretty good food. Love the new set-up since they re-did the place. Kind of makes me feel like an ol' biddy..."Back in my day we stood in this room and listened to bands play..."  My only complaint is that the menu needs to be expanded from just sandwiches....sometimes I want a dish without all that bread...just sayin.

Overall a good place to grab a bite.

Ask the owner for suggestions! He's amazing. I had never had chaat before so he talked me through all the options and eventually just had him give me the most simple item- samosa chaat. 

Be sure to emphasize that vegan because yogurt sauce is a default ingredient.

I've tried every popular cheese steak place in Philly, and hands down Chinks is superior to all of them. Since they make your steak in the order it was ordered, I suggest calling 20 minutes in advance on Saturdays when I've seen it get extremely busy. 

It's not a very large place, but on those not-so-busy-days grab a booth and enjoy your steak fresh off the grill in a place that still looks like a 1955 cut-away. Also, try their cherry coke. They make it the old fashioned way of adding the cherry flavor right there.

Mac n cheese
Burger
Mussels

Eric is the Regina George of bars.. and I love him. And this is the best bar ever.

The teamwork style of service is always just what you need, the beer specials are always interesting and affordable, and there are reasons they have won awards for their food. We always enjoy our meals here!  Great spot for a date with delicious food and an exciting atmosphere with such an eclectic selection of music!

text: This would be 5 stars but my favorite waitress is gone :( she had blonde hair and a lip piercing and I really love her style and I wanna know where she parties. She is powerful. She recommended the black bean burger... yum! It's like she got inside my head and knew exactly what my tastebuds needed. So funny too! Where is she....?
Great place! The dumplings are a little salty but the Mapo tofu and the kung pao chicken are great.
Jones Burgers are good period.  I tried other items but will stick to the burgers they are about $13.50 a little expensive but what the hell.

I dined at R2L with my girlfriend on a recent Saturday night. We were on time for our 8:30 reservation but our table was not available for another 20 minutes. It was a minor inconvenience because we would have had a cocktail anyway. After being seated the service was impeccable for the rest of the meal. The food, however, was hit or miss. We shared the lobster mac n' cheese and tuna carpaccio for appetizers- both were fantastic, setting our expectations high for the entres. I ordered the braised pork over rissotto. While it was flavorful, I felt the meat was dry and the rissotto undercooked. My date ordered the tuna loin and found it slightly disappointed that the chef recommended it cooked medium (not pink at all). The wine menu was extensive and expensive, though we found the options by the glass to be limited and mediocre. The dessert menu was sadly lacking in chocolate options, so we opted for some exotic ice creams. In general the meal was satisfying and the ambiance pleasant. The patrons were half trendy and half stodgy middle agers. It's a fine venue for a special occasion, but for $100/plate I was hoping for something more.

text: I was at a private function here.  Lunch was very good.  I had a fine roast pork sandwich  Cheesesteak empanadas were really special too.

I was extremely disappointed in the service.  
1) We were the only people in the restaurant in the afternoon
2) We ordered milkshakes.  How long does it take to make a milkshake?  We were waiting here for 30-40 min. 

We liked the Village Whiskey in Revel a lot better. Unfortunately that restaurant is no longer around because Revel shut its doors.

We arrived late in the evening. We got to our room and it was only a queen size bed when we had ordered a king size room. When we got to check in we requested a crib and we were told it would be 10 mins. We did not receive the crib until over an hour later. I had to call to check on it, after asking the Bell hop how long it would take. So I had to ask 3 times to get it. The room set up was ridiculous- the air conditioner blew to the window, it did not go  anywhere near the bed. We had to set the air at 60 degrees and it still was not "cool" in our room. They do not supply the rooms with a  microwave or a refrigerator- you have to pay extra for those. 

What I did like was how close it was to everything in downtown philly.  The cleaning lady was very nice and helpful, and the staff was friendly.
The lassis are okay but the chaats could be a lot fresher, i.e., made using fresh ingredients that weren't sitting out all day! An okay place to grab a snack but nothing to get too excited about.

It started with the novelty of getting a breakfast sandwich in center city with veggie sausage and has since grown to a borderline obsession with everything Citi Marketplace. They have an amazing array of delicious vegetarian deli sandwiches made to order (try the veggie chicken salad= amazing) not to mention all the side components you could need for a healthy and satisfying meal. I can honestly say that I have loved everything I've ordered here.   But what really sends them soaring over the top is the staff. So unendingly pleasant and sweet, they can honestly turn your day around.. If I could, I would eat here every day.
I only go when I've had too much to drink and I don't know any better.Steak is dry, fries are bland never seasoned. Chicken fingers are overcooked, very tough. Chicken cheese steak wasn't bad though.
Amazing service and can not be taco Tuesday. Great ownership and solid food. awesome margaritas.

Order delivered was incorrect. I ordered 2 beef but the one that is delivered is beef and the other one was a noodle with rice. And I am not a fan of noodle and rice in a meal.They changed the order without informing me
This was my first time trying a Philly steak! So glad I tried it from Wiz Kid! I had it delivered to my Airbnb so I was not able to see the store and feel the vibe out, 10/10 would recommend!

YOU MUST GO HERE! I just got the sauces you see drizzled on top on the side. But seriously, this was so delicious and hit the spot! It's for perfect for a night when you need something light, but it's still filling. The flavored are amazing, the fish is FRESH, and the gentleman are very helpful! I'm hooked!

Here's a simple review...I love Kanella for many reasons:
Delicious Food: Yes all the time, every time...awesome specials too!
Friendly Service: Not only friendly but attentive, servers know what they're serving...not very common nowadays.
Good Atmosphere: Place is always packed with people, but it still feels cozy, like the "farmhouse you wish you had"'s kitchen table.
Reasonable Prices: I triple checked the bill...I mean... I had dessert, coffee, apps, entree, and side dishes....is this right?

side note: If you see a guy drinking a glass of milk...He's NOT lame...and its not milk! Its "soumada:"...and it's delicious almond liquid nectar of the gods...
....that's all folks!

What better to combat the sweltering summer heat than gelato...artisan gelato at that!

The wait staff were very friendly.  I arrived 20 minutes before my friends and the employees had no problem with me sitting in the AC before I purchased anything.  The wait staff were also very pleasant while I sampled a number of flavors before making my decision: White Peach (not be confused with the regular Peach flavor) that had refreshing little chunks of peaches. 

I also sampled the Avocado (surprisingly nice flavor but *way* too rich and creamy, even for gelato), Thai Coconut (delicious, but a very strong - you have to love coconut!), and Banana Rum (my least favorite as it did not taste like a natural banana flavor).

Though pricey ($4+ for a small cup), it is delicious.  For a single person, you really don't need anything bigger than the smallest size as it is so rich.
Its 11:46 am and the out buttermilk crispy tenders.... BAD MANAGEMENT ... need a New MANAGER

I've been here once with my BFF and it was just so crowed!   There are really busy days from time to time.  We ordered a Hainese? chicken i believe with some kind of special rice.  Mhmm mhmm mmhm, delicious!  Half proportion for both of us and were were so satisfied!  The bill came out to be LESS than 20$!  The atmosphere was pretty cool.

I can understand why this place is pretty popular - the menu has a lot of those guilty pleasure items and the atmosphere is pretty cozy.  

My experience, however, was not that great.  My order was wrong when initially brought out.  I ordered the veggie soy burger and it was just decent.  Stay away from the fries - talk about a sodium induced heart attack.  You know how your lips start to burn and swell when you eat something with too much salt?  If you want Angelina Jolie puckered iips, just go to Jones and order some fries.

One great thing about Jones - amazing martinis!  I ordered the Granny Smith Caramel martini - this is a must try.  It's made with sour apple pucker and the martini glass rim is covered in caramel.  

If I ever went back to Jones, I'd only go for drinks.

It's obvious that Tria must spend a lot of time teaching their staff about wine and cheeses.  Every time I've paid Tria a visit--and those visits have been varied, from afternoon shopping excursions to later-evening noshes to happy hour visits--the staff has known an excellent pairing for wine and cheese.  Part of the fun of visiting a place like Tria is experimenting with the pairings.  If you're not in the mood for heavy eating, but instead want to soak up the ambiance while nibbling at cheese and baguettes, Tria is your place. 

The food menu itself is rather simple, with fare like Smoked Chicken Salad and different sandwiches.  Tria seems to go with local or organic choices for some of its items.  No matter how much I've eaten at Tria or elsewhere, I always like the simple Nutella panini.  Sure, it scrapes the roof of your mouth, but chocolate can sometimes be pain.

The interior is warmly lit and inviting.  The only downside is the seating is limited.  If you want to sit outside, you're forced to sit next to a noisy street with little area for seating.  The servers always seem annoyed when they have to serve you outside as it's an endless trek up and down the front stairs.  Otherwise, the servers are great.  

Another thing to look out for is what Tria calls Sunday School.  Now, I don't know about you, but for me, Sunday School has an entirely different meaning.  For Tria, it means they highlight some cheese, wine, and beer choices, discount them, and give you a little lesson about them.  Obviously, they're not wine snobs, and understand that not everyone was born knowing all the different wine regions of France.  Just my kind of place, because I'm a rather no-frills gal who likes a little frill from time to time.

My girlfriend and I went there after prom, and I have to say that once again Applebees has satisfied my appetite to it's fullest extent. I am a guy who loves meats. Steak, burgers, or chicken. Applebees makes a flawless effort to deem all of these foods irresistible. The seafood is amazing, and I wanted to make the appetizers the main course, they were so good. I did have to wait a while for the food, but I'd say the wait is worth it. I even loved their strawberry lemonade. I guess the only problem with the store is the wait, so please don't go there if you're expecting "fast" food.

I can't believe it's taken me so long to try ants pants but it was worth the wait and lived up to the hype! I came here for brunch on Saturday with a friend around 1045am and we had no problem getting a table- we were able to sit outside in the back grader area which was nice. I ordered an iced chai which was tasty and looked through the menu for food- let me know say there are almost too many options here! There were multiple dishes I wanted to try but ended up getting the hot & sweet bacon egg and cheese roll that came with fries. It was DELICIOUS and super filling - I couldn't even finish the whole sandwich because it was just so much food, and at $10 not a bad price at all! Our server was polite and overall my friend and I had a really nice time here. Pro tip though- ants pants is cash only - there is an ATM in the restaurant but just be aware! I will definitely be coming back here soon!
ner_results: {'food': ['hot & sweet bacon egg and cheese roll', 'fries'], 'drink': ['iced chai']}

It came with delicious greape leaves. I had the sting ray which was awesome. Pork cheeks appetizer was breaded..delicious. The lamb appetizer was unique and good.
